de.hshl.obj.loader

Class Resource

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.hshl.obj.loader.Resource

  • public final class Resource
extends java.lang.Object
    Because OBJ files can reference MTL files in the same folder, it is not enough to know the file location of the OBJ file, but it is also required to know where all related files are located.

    The Resource.Environment specifies where a group of related OBJ or MTL files are located. A Resource.Environment may for example refer to a directory on the filesystem, or a resource folder inside the jar, or even an in-memory byte buffer.

    The Resource class references an environment and a filename to a file in that environment. Together these point to a resource. Use bundled(Path) or file(Path) if you want to open a file-based resource.
    See Also:
    Resource.Environment, getEnvironment(), getName(), getFilePath()

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static interface  Resource.Environment
      A Environment represents a group of related files, for example a folder or a jar resource folder.

      • Resource

                java.lang.String name)

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public java.io.BufferedReader open()
                            throws java.io.IOException
        Open the resource with a buffered reader.
        Returns:
        An open reader which has to be closed by the caller.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If the resource cannot be opened.

      • getFilePath

        @Nullable
public java.nio.file.Path getFilePath()
        If this Resource is made from a file in a folder, returns the file path. Note however that this Path does not remember whether it references a bundled resource or an absolute file.

        Use open() instead if you want to open the file regardless of whether it is bundled or file.

      • bundled

        public static Resource bundled(java.nio.file.Path path)
        Create a new Resource to a file which was bundled inside your jar, or placed in your IntelliJ resource folder. This method internally uses ClassLoader.getResourceAsStream(String).

        Read more about Resources to find out why this is useful.
        Parameters:
        path - The file path of the resource
        Returns:
        The resource of the file
        See Also:
        file(Path)

      • file

        public static Resource file(java.nio.file.Path path)
        Create a new Resource to an external file path. Only use this if your file is inside the "resource folder". Use bundled(Path) instead if you want to open a file inside your jar or an external file relative to your jar.
        Parameters:
        path - The file path of the resource
        Returns:
        The resource of the file

      • getEnvironment

        public Resource.Environment getEnvironment()
        The environment which contains all related files

      • getName

        public java.lang.String getName()
        The name of the file inside the environment of all related files
